I have discovered that my cat starts licking around her neck and her paw if I put pressure and knead around on her vertebrae about 5 inches from her neck. It's so strange. If I hold her head to prevent access, she still tries and her tongue comes out.

It always did look like a reflex to me. If it were a learned behavior, it doesn't look very effective as a way to say, "Keep doing this," when much of the time the kicking tends to move your hand away from the area you're scratching. Plus, it has the rhythm of a reflex rather than a voluntary action. But most dogs do seek and invite it when offered. Not so much cats, though.

I'm guessing the phenomenon described beginning at 0:57 to be not just a function of only light touch triggering the reflex, but also of deep pressure inhibiting it. If I could diagram it, there'd be an addition to the reflex arc whereby the pressure receptors are wired in to an inhibitory synapse either pre- or post-synaptically to the afferent input from the light touch.

I wonder if the kicking reflex is more tied to the actual feeling of having an itch scratched and how quickly their legs move in response - as mentioned dogs are more likely to do it if they're already itchy. But I notice this in my dog (as well as a few other dogs I've met), when I scratch an itch where I saw her scratching earlier she starts to not just kick, but also assumes the position she was in when she was scratching that spot, always the most awkward pose lol. And then her foot will start scratching my hand because it's in the way of that spot, but she's not just trying to do it herself, it's involuntary. It doesn't seem to be exclusive to any part of the body, just whatever is itchy at that moment on the dog.
So I guess what I mean is, maybe it's not parasite related or just a reflex from scratching certain nerves, but the actual scratching itself may be triggering some sort of repetitive kicking response in the muscles. This would rapidly and thoroughly scratch the itch without fine motor skills in the legs being required, stopping once the itchy signals have subsided/the itch has been scratched. If that were the case, it seems most dogs don't really mind the response. But some try to take over the scratching or become uncomfortable that they're feeling the scratchies but their foot isn't actually doing anything. Or maybe some dogs are just weird idk

Quick correction: You wrote "scabies and mange", but scabies actually IS mange. It's known as sarcoptic mange. The other type being demodectic mange, each caused by different types of mites.
